Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Transport in Supported Polyelectrolyte Membranes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Environmental Chemical Sciences (ECS) and the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry (MSN) programs of the Division of Chemistry will support the research program of Prof. Christy Landes of Rice University. Prof. Landes and her research group will develop and apply state of the art single molecule spectroscopic techniques for understanding and controlling transport in charged polymer membranes. The research is thus focused on the water/membrane interface, and will address questions such as how molecules move in charged and crowded environments. The ultimate goal is to be able to predict and control heterogeneous processes in interfacial materials at the molecular scale.

The chemical systems to be studied have direct relevance to the heterogeneous phenomena that occur at the environmental water/soil interface. The project will increase our understanding of how molecular-scale dynamics relate to macro-scale interfacial properties. These topics relate to general large-scale issues such as a future shortage of clean energy and water, and more directly to separations and water purification applications. Students working on this project will receive an excellent educational opportunity because it represents an interdisciplinary research project that relates chemistry, physics, materials science and environmental science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Industrial separations, drug delivery, and water purification all rely on hidden and heterogeneous interactions at membrane interfaces. This CAREER project, entitled “Transport in Supported Polyelectrolyte Membranes”, was funded with the overall goal to identify hidden, complex transport mechanisms at membrane interfaces. The project resulted in the development and application of state of the art single molecule spectroscopic techniques for understanding and controlling transport in charged polymer membranes. The chemical systems studied have direct relevance to the heterogeneous phenomena that occur during commercial purification processes and also at the environmental water/soil interface. The research thus focused on the water/membrane interface, and addressed fundamental questions such as how molecules move in charged and crowded environments.

The most important intellectual outcomes of the work involved the development of exciting new methods to analyze motion in porous environments based on temporal and spatial correlation. Existing methods were insufficient to resolve heterogeneous chemical and physical processes occurring at multiple time and space scales. Traditional methods include electron microscopy, which requires the membranes to be cryo-frozen, prohibiting the measurement of dynamic interactions. Other methods require the membrane to be labeled with a fluorescent tag molecule, which irreparably changes the surface chemistry. The Landes group produced the first method to perform in situ optical imaging of porous membranes within labeling. The new method offers the potential to image chemical processes inside a wide range of porous materials such as bone or the intracellular matrix.

The project increased our understanding of how molecular-scale dynamics drive macro-scale interfacial properties. These topics relate to general large-scale issues such as a future shortage of clean energy and water, and more directly to separations and water purification applications. Charge-based separations dominate both lab and industrial scale purifications. Currently, such processes are optimized by trial-and-error because there is no method to predict the proper purification support matrix or conditions. In a multi-billion dollar separations industry situated on a purely empirical framework, even a small improvement in predictive optimization could have a large impact. The Landes group established the fundamentals that make it possible to predict macro-scale separations based on single-analyte measurements.

Students working on this project have received an excellent educational opportunity because it represents an interdisciplinary research project that relates chemistry, physics, materials science and environmental science. As such, graduate, undergraduate, and postdoctoral trainees have gone on to successful careers in industry and academia both in the US and internationally. The research and education goals in the Landes laboratory rest on the principle that only by looking outside traditional boundaries can we solve the large-scale problems of our future, namely a shortage of clean energy and water sources and a shortage of top-quality scientific leaders.  For example, even though the lab specialty is experimental chemistry, the group has created and made publicly available an Introduction to Programming in Matlab course to emphasize the value of programming to a broader audience. Also, after the 2014 Nobel in Chemistry was awarded for Super-Resolution and Single Molecule Spectroscopy, a Civic Science Lecture was developed relating to the 2014 Nobel to the long and contentious attempt, from the Ancient Greeks through the Enlightenment to the Quantum Era, to understand the nature of light and to overcome the challenges presented by the laws of physics.

Overall, the project resulted in the ability to understand heterogeneous transport and orientation of solutes within a wide range of porous membranes; in new methods optimized for better space and time resolution to study relevant processes; and in successful implementation in realistic separations and purification materials.
